instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display compatibility
threads.message:
Hi,
I've got a display that comes from a dead <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and I don't have another machine of that kind to test it.
Physically it looks similar to the display of an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.
Are they compatible parts ? Can I put it in an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> in order to test it ?

And then, for the sake of completeness, same question but the other way around: will an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> accept a display that comes from an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display compatibility
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> should have True Tone display, and older model are not True Tone.
It may work for test, if LCD layout is the same.
But quality image will be lower and client will not (supposedlly) accept it.

You can get LCD assembly for good price from Aliexpress.
Just be sure to get True Tone version...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display compatibility
threads.message:
There's no client. It's just me collecting dead macbooks from here and there and messing arround with them on my spare time. So nobody will "not accept it" in this case (besides myself) ;)
Yeah, I was also thinking about that True tone thing, which is why I asked the question both ways. I think there's a good chance that an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display would work in an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, but the other way around can be more of a challenge.
But yeah, I was basically trying to see if some people already tried those swaps and if they were successful or not. I assume, based on your response, that you have never tried this yourself ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display compatibility
threads.message:
I didn't try such interchange myself.
If I correctly remember, dukefawkes spoke about them few months ago on the forum.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display compatibility
threads.message:
Ah ok. I did try to search for this in the forum before posting but didn't manage to find anything useful. I'll try again, targeting specifically duke's posts.
And if nothing, I'll cross check one more time the connector pinout to check that signals are indeed compatible, and if so, I'll just give it a try. If the screen works then I know I have a good screen. If it doesn't, then I don't know if that's a bad screen, or just that it's not compatible, or both.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> display compatibility
threads.message:
I think I found the post you were referring to:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-05-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-lcd-issues.58546/post-58568[/URL]
It's not about the same model, in that case it's a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. But basically duke was saying that the display from a non-true tone machine would work in a machine that has true tone, but with brightness issues. He didn't say if a true tone display would work in a non true tone machine though.
So there's only one way for me to find out now. I'll report back later on with my results.
